isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1995) - SUPPLEMENTAL DIAGNOSTIC ANALYSIS - DIAGNOSTIC ANALYIS PROCEDURES FOR FUEL CONSUMPTION

svcproc.title: DIAGNOSTIC ANALYIS PROCEDURES FOR FUEL CONSUMPTION

step1.para: When excessive fuel consumption is suspected, verify the problem;

step2.para: Compare the actual rate of consumption in miles per gallon against normal expected fuel usage in the subject vehicle. Fuel consumption is a factor of load and operating conditions. The greater the load and/or higher speed the engine is operated under, the greater the fuel consumption.
If excessive fuel consumption is confirmed, determine the cause of the problem.

step1.para: Check the entire fuel system for leaks.

step2.para: Check for internal fuel leakage into the lubricating oil. Take an oil sample and have it analyzed for the presence of fuel.
With a regulated air supply, pressurize the fuel system with 30-40 psi of air pressure. Isolate the cause of any leakage.

Perform a cylinder contribution (Engine Running Injector Test) to determine if an injector(s) may be contributing to excessive fuel consumption. Refer to Performance Diagnostics Test 7B on the Hard Start No Start and Performance Diagnostic form EGED-150.

step1.para: Investigate the possibility that the engine is not in proper specs by conducting the Performance Diagnostic tests as indicated on the Hard Start No Start and Performance Diagnostic Form EGED-150 .
Review the driver's habits to be sure he is not lugging or overspeeding the engine.

step2.para: Determine operating conditions when overheating occurs.
Check for overheat related fault codes or event log information with the EST (Electronic Service Tool).
Check the following items:

item.para: Filler cap [pressure cap] on deaeration tank.

step2.para: Vehicle specifications - verify the VPM programing is correct for the vehicle and application.
Accessory equipment - is the equipment approved and installed correctly?
Clean, no oil leaks, no external coolant leaks.
Condition of serpentine belt and tensioner.
Coolant must be clean and properly inhibited for the season.

Deaeration tank (pressure) cap operation. Use pressure test kit Model D200 (ZTSE-2239) or Gauge Bar (PS94-831-3). Check restriction at water pump inlet. Should not exceed 3 in. Hg (10 kPa) without pressure cap, thermostat open and engine at high idle.
Hoses - correct type and properly clamped.
Radiator clean and unobstructed by bent fins, pinched tubes, etc.
Radiator correct. Check repair history or use of "stop leaks". Check specifications of radiator for vehicle.
- Proper specification for vehicle, proper fit in shroud. Properly installed.

Clutch Operation - Fan clutch should be fully engaged at 93-100% of pulley speed with an air temperature at the fan of 165-175F (73.9-79.4C) equivalent to a coolant temperature of 195-205F (90.6-96.1C). Below these temperatures the fan operates at 33-50% of pulley speed.
Shutter control (if equipped) operative and correctly set.
Water pump condition, inspect weep holes for leakage or evidence of leakage.
Thermostat and seal - proper specifications and operating correctly.
cooler - proper flow of both oil and water.
Engine power correct.
Coolant aeration from head gasket or a cracked/porous cylinder head.
